sn22.60:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā vesāliyaṃ viharati mahāvane kūṭāgārasālāyaṃ.
sn22.60:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.

sn22.60:1.3.pli: Atha kho mahāli licchavi yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami …pe… ekamantaṃ nisinno kho mahāli licchavi bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn22.60:1.3.eng: Then Mahāli the Licchavi went up to the Buddha … and said to him:

sn22.60:2.2.eng: ‘There is no cause or reason for the corruption of sentient beings.
sn22.60:2.2.comm: This view is attributed to the Bamboo-staffed Ascetic Gosāla, founder of the Ājīvakas, at DN 2:20.2. There, Pūraṇa Kassapa advocates the inefficacy of action (DN 2:16.1), while at SN 46.56 he is said to teach that there is no cause for knowledge.

sn22.60:2.3.eng: Sentient beings are corrupted without cause or reason.

sn22.60:2.4.pli: Natthi hetu natthi paccayo sattānaṃ visuddhiyā;
sn22.60:2.4.eng: There’s no cause or reason for the purification of sentient beings.

sn22.60:2.5.eng: Sentient beings are purified without cause or reason.’

sn22.60:2.6.eng: What does the Buddha say about this?”

sn22.60:3.1.pli: “Atthi, mahāli, hetu atthi paccayo sattānaṃ saṅkilesāya;
sn22.60:3.1.eng: “Mahāli, there is a cause and reason for the corruption of sentient beings.

sn22.60:3.2.eng: Sentient beings are corrupted with cause and reason.

sn22.60:3.3.pli: Atthi, mahāli, hetu, atthi paccayo sattānaṃ visuddhiyā;
sn22.60:3.3.eng: There is a cause and reason for the purification of sentient beings.

sn22.60:3.4.eng: Sentient beings are purified with cause and reason.”

sn22.60:4.1.pli: “Katamo pana, bhante, hetu katamo paccayo sattānaṃ saṅkilesāya;
sn22.60:4.1.eng: “But sir, what is the cause and reason for the corruption of sentient beings?

sn22.60:4.2.eng: How are sentient beings corrupted with cause and reason?”

sn22.60:5.1.pli: “Rūpañca hidaṃ, mahāli, ekantadukkhaṃ abhavissa dukkhānupatitaṃ dukkhāvakkantaṃ anavakkantaṃ sukhena, nayidaṃ sattā rūpasmiṃ sārajjeyyuṃ.
sn22.60:5.1.eng: “Mahāli, if form were exclusively painful—soaked and steeped in pain and not steeped in pleasure—sentient beings wouldn’t be aroused by it.

sn22.60:5.2.pli: Yasmā ca kho, mahāli, rūpaṃ sukhaṃ sukhānupatitaṃ sukhāvakkantaṃ anavakkantaṃ dukkhena, tasmā sattā rūpasmiṃ sārajjanti;
sn22.60:5.2.eng: But because form is pleasurable—soaked and steeped in pleasure and not steeped in pain—sentient beings are aroused by it.

sn22.60:5.3.eng: Since they are aroused by it, they’re caught up in it, and so they become corrupted.

sn22.60:5.4.pli: Ayaṃ kho, mahāli, hetu, ayaṃ paccayo sattānaṃ saṅkilesāya;
sn22.60:5.4.eng: This is a cause and reason for the corruption of sentient beings.

sn22.60:5.5.eng: This is how sentient beings are corrupted with cause and reason.

sn22.60:6.1.pli: Vedanā ca hidaṃ, mahāli, ekantadukkhā abhavissa dukkhānupatitā dukkhāvakkantā anavakkantā sukhena, nayidaṃ sattā vedanāya sārajjeyyuṃ.

sn22.60:6.2.pli: Yasmā ca kho, mahāli, vedanā sukhā sukhānupatitā sukhāvakkantā anavakkantā dukkhena, tasmā sattā vedanāya sārajjanti;

sn22.60:6.5.pli: Ayampi kho, mahāli, hetu, ayaṃ paccayo sattānaṃ saṅkilesāya.

sn22.60:7.2.pli: saṅkhārā ca hidaṃ, mahāli, ekantadukkhā abhavissaṃsu dukkhānupatitā dukkhāvakkantā anavakkantā sukhena, nayidaṃ sattā saṅkhāresu sārajjeyyuṃ.

sn22.60:7.3.pli: Yasmā ca kho, mahāli, saṅkhārā sukhā sukhānupatitā sukhāvakkantā anavakkantā dukkhena, tasmā sattā saṅkhāresu sārajjanti;

sn22.60:7.6.pli: Ayampi kho, mahāli, hetu, ayaṃ paccayo sattānaṃ saṅkilesāya.

sn22.60:8.1.pli: Viññāṇañca hidaṃ, mahāli, ekantadukkhaṃ abhavissa dukkhānupatitaṃ dukkhāvakkantaṃ anavakkantaṃ sukhena, nayidaṃ sattā viññāṇasmiṃ sārajjeyyuṃ.
sn22.60:8.1.eng: consciousness were exclusively painful—soaked and steeped in pain and not steeped in pleasure—sentient beings wouldn’t be aroused by it.

sn22.60:8.2.pli: Yasmā ca kho, mahāli, viññāṇaṃ sukhaṃ sukhānupatitaṃ sukhāvakkantaṃ anavakkantaṃ dukkhena, tasmā sattā viññāṇasmiṃ sārajjanti;
sn22.60:8.2.eng: But because consciousness is pleasurable—soaked and steeped in pleasure and not steeped in pain—sentient beings are aroused by it.

sn22.60:8.3.eng: Since they are aroused by it, they’re caught up in it, and so they become corrupted.

sn22.60:8.4.pli: Ayampi kho, mahāli, hetu ayaṃ paccayo sattānaṃ saṅkilesāya.
sn22.60:8.4.eng: This is a cause and reason for the corruption of sentient beings.

sn22.60:8.5.eng: This is how sentient beings are corrupted with cause and reason.”

sn22.60:9.1.pli: “Katamo pana, bhante, hetu katamo paccayo sattānaṃ visuddhiyā;
sn22.60:9.1.eng: “But sir, what is the cause and reason for the purification of sentient beings?

sn22.60:9.2.eng: How are sentient beings purified with cause and reason?”

sn22.60:9.3.pli: “Rūpañca hidaṃ, mahāli, ekantasukhaṃ abhavissa sukhānupatitaṃ sukhāvakkantaṃ anavakkantaṃ dukkhena, nayidaṃ sattā rūpasmiṃ nibbindeyyuṃ.
sn22.60:9.3.eng: “Mahāli, if form was perfectly pleasurable—soaked and steeped in pleasure and not steeped in pain—sentient beings wouldn’t grow disillusioned with it.

sn22.60:9.4.pli: Yasmā ca kho, mahāli, rūpaṃ dukkhaṃ dukkhānupatitaṃ dukkhāvakkantaṃ anavakkantaṃ sukhena, tasmā sattā rūpasmiṃ nibbindanti;
sn22.60:9.4.eng: But because form is painful—soaked and steeped in pain and not steeped in pleasure—sentient beings do grow disillusioned with it.

sn22.60:9.5.eng: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they are purified.

sn22.60:9.6.pli: Ayaṃ kho, mahāli, hetu, ayaṃ paccayo, sattānaṃ visuddhiyā.
sn22.60:9.6.eng: This is a cause and reason for the purification of sentient beings.

sn22.60:9.7.eng: This is how sentient beings are purified with cause and reason.

sn22.60:10.1.pli: Vedanā ca hidaṃ, mahāli, ekantasukhā abhavissa …pe…

sn22.60:10.3.pli: saṅkhārā ca hidaṃ, mahāli, ekantasukhā abhavissaṃsu …pe…

sn22.60:10.4.pli: viññāṇañca hidaṃ, mahāli, ekantasukhaṃ abhavissa sukhānupatitaṃ sukhāvakkantaṃ anavakkantaṃ dukkhena, nayidaṃ sattā viññāṇasmiṃ nibbindeyyuṃ.
sn22.60:10.4.eng: consciousness was perfectly pleasurable—soaked and steeped in pleasure and not steeped in pain—sentient beings wouldn’t grow disillusioned with it.

sn22.60:10.5.pli: Yasmā ca kho, mahāli, viññāṇaṃ dukkhaṃ dukkhānupatitaṃ dukkhāvakkantaṃ anavakkantaṃ sukhena, tasmā sattā viññāṇasmiṃ nibbindanti;
sn22.60:10.5.eng: But because consciousness is painful—soaked and steeped in pain and not steeped in pleasure—sentient beings do grow disillusioned with it.

sn22.60:10.6.eng: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they are purified.

sn22.60:10.7.pli: Ayaṃ kho, mahāli, hetu, ayaṃ paccayo, sattānaṃ visuddhiyā.
sn22.60:10.7.eng: This is a cause and reason for the purification of sentient beings.

sn22.60:10.8.eng: This is how sentient beings are purified with cause and reason.”

sn22.61:1.2.pli: “Rūpaṃ, bhikkhave, ādittaṃ, vedanā ādittā, saññā ādittā, saṅkhārā ādittā, viññāṇaṃ ādittaṃ.
sn22.61:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness are burning.
sn22.61:1.2.comm: The third discourse famously taught that the six senses are “burning” (SN 35.28), and here the Buddha applies the same metaphor to the aggregates.

sn22.61:1.3.pli: Evaṃ passaṃ, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako rūpasmimpi nibbindati, vedanāyapi … saññāyapi … saṅkhāresupi … viññāṇasmimpi nibbindati.
sn22.61:1.3.eng: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.

sn22.61:1.4.pli: Nibbindaṃ virajjati; virāgā vimuccati. Vimuttasmiṃ vimuttamiti ñāṇaṃ hoti.
sn22.61:1.4.eng: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.

sn22.61:1.5.pli: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānātī”ti.
sn22.61:1.5.eng: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’”

sn22.62:1.2.pli: “Tayome, bhikkhave, niruttipathā adhivacanapathā paññattipathā asaṅkiṇṇā asaṅkiṇṇapubbā, na saṅkīyanti, na saṅkīyissanti, appaṭikuṭṭhā samaṇehi brāhmaṇehi viññūhi.
sn22.62:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, there are these three scopes of definition, labeling, and description. They’re uncorrupted, as they have been since the beginning. They’re not being corrupted now, nor will they be. Sensible ascetics and brahmins don’t look down on them.
sn22.62:1.2.comm: The three “scopes” or “ranges” (patha) are the past, present, and future, each of which is indicated by the appropriate grammatical tense. | Nirutti means the “clear expression” or “definition” of a word. In the pre-Buddhist literature, that which is “undefined” is the mystical truth to be muttered under the breath, whereas that which is “defined” is clearly expressed in language. A list of such definitions is a nirukti, a glossary or dictionary. See DN 15:32.11, MN 139:13.55, and AN 5.169:3.6.

sn22.62:1.4.pli: Yaṃ, bhikkhave, rūpaṃ atītaṃ niruddhaṃ vipariṇataṃ ‘ahosī’ti tassa saṅkhā, ‘ahosī’ti tassa samaññā, ‘ahosī’ti tassa paññatti;
sn22.62:1.4.eng: When form has passed, ceased, and perished, its designation, label, and description is ‘was’.

sn22.62:1.5.pli: na tassa saṅkhā ‘atthī’ti, na tassa saṅkhā ‘bhavissatī’ti.
sn22.62:1.5.comm: The purpose of this argument is to rebut the idea that “being” or “existence” is eternal, and change an illusion. The Buddha points out that ordinary usage describes things that exist as impermanent, and thus the eternalist thesis contradicts the commonly-agreed truth. This passage is cited in Kv 1.7 against the Sarvāstivādin thesis that all phenomena of past, present, and future, exist (also discussed at Kv 1.6 and Kv 1.8).

sn22.62:2.1.pli: Yā vedanā atītā niruddhā vipariṇatā ‘ahosī’ti tassā saṅkhā, ‘ahosī’ti tassā samaññā, ‘ahosī’ti tassā paññatti;

sn22.62:2.2.pli: na tassā saṅkhā ‘atthī’ti, na tassā saṅkhā ‘bhavissatī’ti.

sn22.62:3.2.pli: ye saṅkhārā atītā niruddhā vipariṇatā ‘ahesun’ti tesaṃ saṅkhā, ‘ahesun’ti tesaṃ samaññā, ‘ahesun’ti tesaṃ paññatti;

sn22.62:3.3.pli: na tesaṃ saṅkhā ‘atthī’ti, na tesaṃ saṅkhā ‘bhavissantī’ti.

sn22.62:4.1.pli: Yaṃ viññāṇaṃ atītaṃ niruddhaṃ vipariṇataṃ, ‘ahosī’ti tassa saṅkhā, ‘ahosī’ti tassa samaññā, ‘ahosī’ti tassa paññatti;
sn22.62:4.1.eng: consciousness has passed, ceased, and perished, its designation, label, and description is ‘was’.

sn22.62:4.2.pli: na tassa saṅkhā ‘atthī’ti, na tassa saṅkhā ‘bhavissatī’ti.

sn22.62:5.1.pli: Yaṃ, bhikkhave, rūpaṃ ajātaṃ apātubhūtaṃ, ‘bhavissatī’ti tassa saṅkhā, ‘bhavissatī’ti tassa samaññā, ‘bhavissatī’ti tassa paññatti;
sn22.62:5.1.eng: When form is not yet born, and has not yet appeared, its designation, label, and description is ‘will be’.

sn22.62:5.2.pli: na tassa saṅkhā ‘atthī’ti, na tassa saṅkhā ‘ahosī’ti.

sn22.62:6.1.pli: Yā vedanā ajātā apātubhūtā, ‘bhavissatī’ti tassā saṅkhā, ‘bhavissatī’ti tassā samaññā, ‘bhavissatī’ti tassā paññatti;

sn22.62:6.2.pli: na tassā saṅkhā ‘atthī’ti, na tassā saṅkhā ‘ahosī’ti.

sn22.62:7.2.pli: ye saṅkhārā ajātā apātubhūtā, ‘bhavissantī’ti tesaṃ saṅkhā, ‘bhavissantī’ti tesaṃ samaññā, ‘bhavissantī’ti tesaṃ paññatti;

sn22.62:7.3.pli: na tesaṃ saṅkhā ‘atthī’ti, na tesaṃ saṅkhā ‘ahesun’ti.

sn22.62:8.1.pli: Yaṃ viññāṇaṃ ajātaṃ apātubhūtaṃ, ‘bhavissatī’ti tassa saṅkhā, ‘bhavissatī’ti tassa samaññā, ‘bhavissatī’ti tassa paññatti;
sn22.62:8.1.eng: consciousness is not yet born, and has not yet appeared, its designation, label, and description is ‘will be’.

sn22.62:8.2.pli: na tassa saṅkhā ‘atthī’ti, na tassa saṅkhā ‘ahosī’ti.

sn22.62:9.1.pli: Yaṃ, bhikkhave, rūpaṃ jātaṃ pātubhūtaṃ, ‘atthī’ti tassa saṅkhā, ‘atthī’ti tassa samaññā, ‘atthī’ti tassa paññatti;
sn22.62:9.1.eng: When form has been born, and has appeared, its designation, label, and description is ‘is’.

sn22.62:9.2.pli: na tassa saṅkhā ‘ahosī’ti, na tassa saṅkhā ‘bhavissatī’ti.

sn22.62:10.1.pli: Yā vedanā jātā pātubhūtā, ‘atthī’ti tassā saṅkhā, ‘atthī’ti tassā samaññā, ‘atthī’ti tassā paññatti;

sn22.62:10.2.pli: na tassā saṅkhā ‘ahosī’ti, na tassā saṅkhā ‘bhavissatī’ti.

sn22.62:11.2.pli: ye saṅkhārā jātā pātubhūtā, ‘atthī’ti tesaṃ saṅkhā, ‘atthī’ti tesaṃ samaññā, ‘atthī’ti tesaṃ paññatti;

sn22.62:11.3.pli: na tesaṃ saṅkhā ‘ahesun’ti, na tesaṃ saṅkhā, ‘bhavissantī’ti.

sn22.62:12.1.pli: Yaṃ viññāṇaṃ jātaṃ pātubhūtaṃ, ‘atthī’ti tassa saṅkhā, ‘atthī’ti tassa samaññā, ‘atthī’ti tassa paññatti;
sn22.62:12.1.eng: consciousness has been born, and has appeared, its designation, label, and description is ‘is’.

sn22.62:12.2.pli: na tassa saṅkhā ‘ahosī’ti, na tassa saṅkhā ‘bhavissatī’ti.

sn22.62:13.1.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, tayo niruttipathā adhivacanapathā paññattipathā asaṅkiṇṇā asaṅkiṇṇapubbā, na saṅkīyanti, na saṅkīyissanti, appaṭikuṭṭhā samaṇehi brāhmaṇehi viññūhi.
sn22.62:13.1.eng: These are the three scopes of definition, labeling, and description. They’re uncorrupted, as they have been since the beginning. They’re not being corrupted now, nor will they be. Sensible ascetics and brahmins don’t look down on them.

sn22.62:13.2.pli: Yepi te, bhikkhave, ahesuṃ ukkalā vassabhaññā ahetukavādā akiriyavādā natthikavādā, tepime tayo niruttipathe adhivacanapathe paññattipathe na garahitabbaṃ nappaṭikkositabbaṃ amaññiṃsu.
sn22.62:13.2.eng: Even those those who were loud and bold advocates of the doctrines of no-cause, inaction, and nihilism, didn’t imagine that these three scopes of definition should be criticized or rejected.
sn22.62:13.2.comm: The phrase ukkalā vassabhaññā occurs regarding different teachings at MN 117:38.1 and SN 22.62:13.2. The commentary says it refers to two individuals named Vassa and Bhañña from a distant land on the Bay of Bengal, Ukkalā (Sanskrit oḍra, modern Odisha). But this seems quite unlikely. Ukkalā was distant and largely unknown, mentioned only once elsewhere in the Pali canon (Kd 1:4.2.1). These teachers with their odd names (“Rain” and “Speak”) appear nowhere else, yet the the phrase yepi te ahesuṁ suggests they were well known; it is elsewhere used only of “those who were” Buddhas of the past. There seems no reason the Buddha should abruptly allude to such obscure figures as if they were an authority. Read ukkalā from root kal (“to sound”) with prefix ud (“up”), “with raised voice” (cf. Sanskrit kalabhāṣin, “with pleasing voice”). Then vassa from vṛṣa (“bull, chief”), for which compare the expression, uḷārā āsabhī vācā bhāsitā, “spoke a lofty bull’s word”, i.e. made a proud and bold statement. Bhañña is used elsewhere of speaking “out of faith” (pasādabhañña, Bu Pj 4:8.11.8) or of the intoned recitation used for Buddhist texts (sarabhañña, Ud 5.6:18.2 = Kd 15:3.2.1, Kd 15:3.2.1, Kd 22:1.10.5). Thus the sense would be, “those who loudly and boldly assert”.

sn22.62:13.4.eng: For fear of being blamed, attacked, provoked, and faulted.”

sn22.63:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
sn22.63:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

sn22.63:1.3.pli: Atha kho aññataro bhikkhu yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn22.63:1.3.eng: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,

sn22.63:1.4.pli: “sādhu me, bhante, bhagavā saṅkhittena dhammaṃ desetu yamahaṃ bhagavato dhammaṃ sutvā eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto vihareyyan”ti.
sn22.63:1.4.eng: “Sir, may the Buddha please teach me Dhamma in brief. When I’ve heard it, I’ll live alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute.”

sn22.63:1.5.eng: “When you grasp, mendicant, you’re bound by Māra.

sn22.63:1.6.eng: Not grasping, you’re free from the Wicked One.”

sn22.63:2.1.pli: “Yathā kathaṃ pana tvaṃ, bhikkhu, mayā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa vitthārena atthaṃ ājānāsī”ti?
sn22.63:2.1.eng: “But how do you see the detailed meaning of my brief statement?”

sn22.63:2.2.eng: “Sir, when you grasp form you’re bound by Māra.

sn22.63:2.3.eng: Not grasping, you’re free from the Wicked One.

sn22.63:2.9.eng: Not grasping, you’re free from the Wicked One.

sn22.63:2.10.pli: Imassa khvāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavatā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa evaṃ vitthārena atthaṃ ājānāmī”ti.
sn22.63:2.10.eng: That’s how I understand the detailed meaning of the Buddha’s brief statement.”

sn22.63:3.2.pli: Sādhu kho tvaṃ, bhikkhu, mayā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa vitthārena atthaṃ ājānāsi.
sn22.63:3.2.eng: It’s good that you understand the detailed meaning of what I’ve said in brief like this.

sn22.63:3.3.pli: Rūpaṃ kho, bhikkhu, upādiyamāno baddho mārassa;
sn22.63:3.3.eng: When you grasp form you’re bound by Māra.

sn22.63:3.4.eng: Not grasping, you’re free from the Wicked One.

sn22.63:3.9.eng: Not grasping, you’re free from the Wicked One.

sn22.63:3.10.pli: Imassa kho, bhikkhu, mayā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa evaṃ vitthārena attho daṭṭhabbo”ti.
sn22.63:3.10.eng: This is how to understand the detailed meaning of what I said in brief.”

sn22.63:4.1.pli: Atha kho so bhikkhu bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pakkāmi.
sn22.63:4.1.eng: And then that mendicant approved and agreed with what the Buddha said. He got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.

sn22.63:4.2.pli: Atha kho so bhikkhu eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto nacirasseva—yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṃ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.
sn22.63:4.2.eng: Then that mendicant, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, soon realized the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. He lived having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

sn22.63:4.3.pli: “Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā”ti abbhaññāsi.
sn22.63:4.3.eng: He understood: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is nothing further for this place.”

sn22.63:4.4.pli: Aññataro ca pana so bhikkhu arahataṃ ahosīti.
sn22.63:4.4.eng: And that mendicant became one of the perfected.

sn22.64:1.2.pli: Atha kho aññataro bhikkhu …pe… ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn22.64:1.2.eng: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha … and asked him,

sn22.64:1.3.pli: “sādhu me, bhante, bhagavā saṅkhittena dhammaṃ desetu …pe… ātāpī pahitatto vihareyyan”ti.
sn22.64:1.3.eng: “Sir, may the Buddha please teach me Dhamma in brief. When I’ve heard it, I’ll live alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute.”

sn22.64:1.4.eng: “When you conceive, mendicant, you’re bound by Māra.
sn22.64:1.4.comm: To “conceive” or “imagine” (maññati) is, according to the commentary, to think in terms of a “self”, proliferating experience through craving, conceit, or views until it is constructed for me. This usage draws upon such passages as Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 4.3.20, where due to ignorance, a person “imagines” in a dream the fearful things they saw when awake, or at the highest level, “imagines I am this all” (ahamevedaṁ sarvo’smīti manyate). See MN 1:3.3.

sn22.64:1.5.eng: Not conceiving, you’re free from the Wicked One.”

sn22.64:2.1.pli: “Yathā kathaṃ pana tvaṃ, bhikkhu, mayā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa vitthārena atthaṃ ājānāsī”ti?
sn22.64:2.1.eng: “But how do you see the detailed meaning of my brief statement?”

sn22.64:2.2.eng: “Sir, when you conceive form you’re bound by Māra.

sn22.64:2.3.eng: Not conceiving, you’re free from the Wicked One.

sn22.64:2.8.eng: Not conceiving, you’re free from the Wicked One.

sn22.64:2.9.eng: That’s how I understand the detailed meaning of the Buddha’s brief statement.”

sn22.64:3.2.eng: It’s good that you understand the detailed meaning of what I’ve said in brief like this.

sn22.64:3.3.pli: Rūpaṃ kho, bhikkhu, maññamāno baddho mārassa;
sn22.64:3.3.eng: When you conceive form you’re bound by Māra.

sn22.64:3.4.eng: Not conceiving, you’re free from the Wicked One.

sn22.64:3.9.eng: Not conceiving, you’re free from the Wicked One.

sn22.64:3.11.pli: aññataro ca pana so bhikkhu arahataṃ ahosīti.
sn22.64:3.11.eng: And that mendicant became one of the perfected.
